_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. The Facility Policy 



The owners, management and employees of Co-Alliance, LLP should a release occur, are prepared to work with the various fire departments or other authorities. To mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information.



a The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.





b  Aqua ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for both direct application and for blending into mixed grade fertilizers for crop production nutrients.



c The maximum quantity stored would be 648000 pounds in all of our storage tanks. The largest of which is 30000 gallons. 



3. The Worst Case Release Scenario And The Alternative Release Scenario. 



a. The worst case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank released as a Liquid over 10 minutes. The maximum quantity released would be 216000 lbs which  represents the volume of the largest storage tank at capacity as limited by design standards. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 PPM) is 1.2  miles.  This release would have off-site impacts.



b The alternative release scenario based on the five year accident history (or the most likely potential incident) is a release from a break or tear in a transfer pipe or gasket releasing 5250lbs.  This pipe is used to transfer product. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 PPM) is .3 miles.  This release would have off-site impacts.



4. The Accidental Release Prevention Program



The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K61.1", published by The American National Standards institute, inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia". This facility has also complie

d with the Indiana Ammonia Law regulated by the Office of the State Chemist.



5. The five-year Accident History 



A Valparaiso Agronomy has not had any releases  or caused any deaths, injuries, or significant properly damage at the facility; or offsite.





6. The Emergency Response Program



The facility has:





a.  Written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;



b.  Provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right to know information as required under SARA Title 111 (EPCRA).



c.  Written emergency response program. In accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre emergency planning and employee training.



7. Planned Changes To Improve Safety.



Safety improvement is an on going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
